Climate change will affect the production of staple crops, such as maize, and the stability of global food production. Here, we quantify the impact of climate change on maize production and yield variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex cognitive skill we have. How the human brain processes language is therefore a central question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that deep learning models that predict well on a large number of unrelated language tasks also predict well in a brain-imaging study in which the same models are used to analyze neural responses. They also suggest that the models’ architecture may contribute to the brain’s representation of language. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in quantum many-body systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is exact in a scaling limit and holds for a wide class of models. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been responsible for the deaths of millions of people in the past and continues to be a threat to human health. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a better understanding of the history of plague and may help to develop more effective control strategies.

Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, our results suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the precise nature of its function in normal cells must be clarified before this can be achieved. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better health, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is associated with positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes over time. The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of aquatic mammals. Here, we use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes is driven by the aquatic environment and is not a consequence of the release from size constraints.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. This study demonstrates that the replication of rhinovirus is temperature dependent, and that the replication is more efficient at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at the body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings provide insights into the temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of the common cold. Copyright © 2015. Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen to attach to surfaces and for the regulation of virulence factors. Our results thus provide a new mechanism for how bacteria can sense surfaces and how they can use mechanical signals to regulate their behavior. This work also demonstrates that type IV pili can be used as a mechanochemical sensor. This is an important finding because it suggests that the mechanical activity of pili can be used to measure the mechanical properties of the environment. This could have important implications for understanding how bacteria sense and respond to their environment.

We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is not reflected in the monitoring data. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and may have been transmitted from animals to humans. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species of conservation concern. We also show that the virus has spread between deer and humans. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon economy. This is a good thing. However, the development of renewable energy sources must be done in a way that does not harm the environment and people. The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a case in point. The paper examines the problems and solutions.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of extensive research. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the disease is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type in the brain, are also involved in the AD pathogenesis. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons produce a variety of potent immune factors, which are known to be involved in the initiation of the inflammatory response. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. It is a main source of protein for more than one billion people worldwide. However, the question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Hellenistic period. We further show that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by at least a century by the adoption in the Southern Levant.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by the enzyme ApaH, which is inactivated by stress conditions that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that, in the presence of stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli, and that it prefers to decape Np4-capped RNAs over their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts. This preference is due to a unique mechanism of substrate recognition, in which the δ-phosphate of the Np4 cap is positioned for attack by the active site of the enzyme, generating a monophosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This work reveals a previously unknown role for RppH in RNA metabolism and provides a mechanistic explanation for the differential impact of Np4 on the rates at which capped and noncapped RNAs are degraded. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major health problem, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is needed. We have shown that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We have also shown that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is able to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can be in a critical state and yet exhibit no external control. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a model of SOC. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is used in many applications, including cutting tools, surgical tools, and high-performance electronics. However, diamond is brittle and has a low ductility. It is therefore difficult to deform it to achieve its full potential. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, or made to have a metallic electronic band structure, without phonon instability. This opens up new opportunities for diamond to be used in electronic applications. Our findings can also be used to control the phase of diamond, which is important for understanding the origin of its properties. This work provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond for applications. It also provides a platform for future research on the properties of other materials.

The role of plant immunity in the control of fungal pathogens is well established. However, the molecular mechanisms of action of many of the plant defense peptides are not known. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific peptides. The peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides and induces reactive oxygen species. It also penetrates the fungal cell wall and membrane, and accumulates in the cytoplasm and nucleoli of germlings. The peptide is highly effective against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work illustrates the potential of a structurally unique peptide to be developed as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of Drosophila sperm during their posttesticular life history. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and to the public interested in the reproductive biology of Drosophila and other insects. This article is protected by copyright. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping them stick to the vessel wall and stop bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can switch the VWF molecule to a second state with faster binding, explaining the pathophysiology of VWD. This mechanism is general and can be used to understand other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface. It also suggests a way to treat VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database is available to the public and can be used to study the human virome in a wide variety of contexts.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations.

The temperature of the surface environment has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface environment in turn is controlled by the temperature of the surface radiation. Thus, the temperature of the surface environment is a function of the temperature of the surface radiation. This study demonstrates that the temperature of the surface radiation was high in the Archean, a finding consistent with both geologic and isotopic evidence. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that the temperature of the surface radiation has been decreasing over geological time.

Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 1 million deaths annually. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host erythrocyte to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This could lead to the development of new strategies to control the disease.

It is therefore difficult to deform it to achieve its full potential. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, or made to have a metallic electronic band structure, without phonon instability. This opens up new opportunities for diamond to be used in electronic applications. Our findings can also be used to control the phase of diamond, which is important for understanding the origin of its properties. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine and antiviral therapy. The brain is thought to build a hierarchical syntactic structure of sentences, but there is no direct evidence for this claim. Here, we show that the brain encodes the structure of sentences as a hierarchy of nested phrases. We used intracranial recordings to show that the brain encodes the structure of sentences as a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our findings have implications for the design of artificial intelligence systems and for our understanding of the neural basis of language.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway. It is a scaffold that converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. In vertebrates, there are two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Obesity is a major health problem in the United States and worldwide. The causes of obesity are complex and include genetic, environmental, and behavioral factors. Here we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. This effect is blocked by dopamine receptor antagonists and lesions of dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of neurons in the lateral hypothalamus and in the ventral tegmental area that project to the lateral hypothalamus. Finally, we show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of neurons in the lateral hypothalamus that project to the locus coeruleus, a brain region that is important for the regulation of feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

Symbiotic associations between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria are essential for plant growth and productivity. However, the nitrogenase enzyme, which fixes atmospheric nitrogen, is not active in the plant environment. We have developed a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the nitrogenase is activated only when the bacteria are in contact with the host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture and to develop sustainable nitrogen-fixing biofertilizers. This article is protected by copyright. The Amazon is in the midst of a deforestation crisis. The crisis is driven by the expansion of agriculture and cattle ranching, which are often driven by the demand for commodities. The crisis is also driven by the lack of effective monitoring of the drivers of deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to address the crisis. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities in the Peruvian Amazon. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the small number of communities in the experiment. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The hearing organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s hearing is outsourced to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider can hear and localize sound sources without a body, and it can also adjust and regenerate the web to suit its needs. This provides a unique model for studying the sensing and regenerative properties of extended and self-manufactured sensing organs. It also provides inspiration for the design of novel acoustic flow detectors.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results indicate that the benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and other anthropogenic sources are comparable to the benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions alone.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The global distribution of the disease has been hampered by the lack of a vaccine. Here we report the design of a SARS-CoV-2 vaccine antigen that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This engineered antigen is based on a sequence variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) that mediates viral entry to cells. The engineered RBD exhibits high-yield manufacturability, high-affinity binding to ACE2, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence used in current vaccines. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD may be a useful antigen for a variety of vaccine platforms and may be used to develop a vaccine that is accessible and affordable for the global population. The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in the development of many human cancers. In the zebrafish, the Ltk/Alk receptor tyrosine kinase is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the skin. Here, we show that the zebrafish Alk/Ltk receptor tyrosine kinase is also involved in the development of iridophores. We further show that the zebrafish Alkals can activate the human ALK receptor tyrosine kinase. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALK family of receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is important for understanding the role of ALK family receptors in human cancers. Our results also provide a model for studying the role of ALK family receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Finally, our results provide a model for studying the role of ALKALs in human cancers.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of life. We present 17 ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic was already widespread in Eurasia at this time, and that the plague pathogen rapidly spread across continents. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague.

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is a key feature of the Trump era. This work examined the extent to which HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols has led to massive SOC losses. Here, we show that soil health management practices that increase soil organic matter and microbial biomass, such as incorporating legumes and manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. However, these practices did not significantly increase mineral-associated organic matter, which is the most recalcitrant fraction of SOC. In contrast, rotational grazing of pastures managed with rotational grazing increased mineral-associated organic matter and total SOC storage. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester persistent SOC on Mollisols. Thus, grasslands can play a key role in climate-smart agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential. We hope that this work will inform research and public health interventions to prevent and control future outbreaks. The SpillOver database is a living, interactive platform that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that many flowering plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often an important factor in attracting pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this color in other plants. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction.

The genetic history of Europe during the last millennium is poorly understood. This is due to the lack of population-level genome data from the period. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 470 and 670 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly modern, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the ability to detect and respond to emerging pathogens is limited. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and HIV. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS as a resource-efficient and scalable approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied to other resource-scarce settings to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and mitigate the spread of infectious diseases. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The stability of the polymerase–sliding clamp complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the polymerase–sliding clamp complex. We found that the human pol δ–PCNA complex maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique perspective on the stability of the polymerase–sliding clamp complex and the implications of this stability on DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. The RNA world hypothesis proposes that life on Earth began with the evolution of RNA-based enzymes that replicated and catalyzed reactions. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules. This is a significant step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world because it allows the replication of RNA, which is a prerequisite for the evolution of genetic information. Furthermore, the polymerase can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold, which is a key step toward the development of a synthetic PCR. Thus, the polymerase can be used to build a functional RNA world in the laboratory.

Urban change is a major topic of urban studies. However, the physical dynamics of urban change are not well understood. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and other types of imagery. We hope that it will be useful to urban scholars.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is difficult. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-6 pathways, can improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, diagenesis products, and/or fracture/vein fill. The tridymite is a potential indicator of high-temperature, high-pressure conditions in the sediment source region or at the depositional site. The amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, diagenesis products, and/or fracture/vein fill. The source of the amorphous material is not clear, but it is possible that it is a residue of acidic leaching in the sediment source region or at Marias Pass. The post lithification fracture/vein fill is most likely a product of aqueous solutions.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are region-specific and that these strategies are changing. Our findings can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to Th17 cells are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype and is unable to induce colitis in recipients, whereas the other subset, which is dependent on Stat4 and T-bet, is required for the development of colitis. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms that give rise to these subsets will provide insights into the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the mechanisms of disease progression are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of new therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Ticks are vectors for numerous human pathogens. However, the ways infectious agents influence their vectors to enhance colonization are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota to more efficiently colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These changes facilitate the pathogen’s ability to colonize the vector. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will aid in the development of new strategies to control tick-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of vertebrates. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that has been poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early members. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand it completely. However, we can understand some aspects of it. One of these is the role of water vapor in the climate system. We show here that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can affect its ability to blend in with its environment. In this study, we show that the color of some vertebrates can evolve multiple times. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes cancer stem cells are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on messenger RNA. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α. ALKBH5 expression is required for hypoxia-induced enrichment of cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for cancer treatment. Our findings may also have implications for understanding the role of m6A modification in the regulation of pluripotency factors in embryonic stem cells. This article is protected by copyright. The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the extinction is well established. The age model for the extinction is based on a new set of U-Pb dates from the Meishan section in China. The new dates confirm that the extinction occurred between 251.9 and 251.8 Ma, and they also show that the carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction. The carbon cycle volatility is followed by a return to near preextinction values, suggesting that the ecosystem had recovered by the Triassic. The new dates also allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent and pulse-and-slow processes in the extinction. The new age model will be used to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The results will help to improve our understanding of the causes of the extinction and the mechanisms that led to the recovery of the ecosystem.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a complex disease with multiple underlying mechanisms. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to excessive NF-κB signaling in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs), which in turn results in the up-regulation of inflammatory genes and the development of IBD. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating variants. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike with and without this mutation. We find that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. This may explain the increased transmissibility of the variants that contain this mutation.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Fudenberg and Levine (1989) to the case of tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The chemical behavior of matter under pressure is a topic of great interest, both from a fundamental and an applied point of view. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show that our results are consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of matter. Furthermore, we show that our results can be used to predict the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can release large amounts of carbon into the atmosphere. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a large impact on the future trajectory of fire activity. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowed by up to 0.11 °C by 2100, but that this effect is most likely to occur under lower emissions scenarios. Our findings highlight the importance of human ignitions and fire suppression in shaping the future of fire regimes and the climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thus able to maintain a healthy population level only during the night. This is the first example of a host regulating the provision of a single nutrient to a specific symbiont, and it suggests that the provision of nutrients to specific symbionts may be a more common phenomenon than previously thought. Text data are ubiquitous and have been used to study a wide range of topics. However, the latent patterns in text data are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. It can also be used to identify gender biases in topics. Our method can be applied to any corpus of text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The identity of the putative reservoirs of the bacterium Yersinia pestis is still debated. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were highly correlated, and that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were strongly linked to the Asian plague situation. Our results provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the disease was not established in Europe before the climate conditions were favorable for its spread.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a valuable resource for the seafood industry. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of a wasting disease. The disease is characterized by behavioral changes, lesions, loss of turgor, limb autotomy, and death. Here, we provide evidence that the disease is caused by a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the overall survival of AML patients remains poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling is effective in suppressing the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Thus, our findings may lead to the development of novel and more efficient therapies for AML. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement of the island. However, the distribution of the ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent events. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (denoted GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. The RNA also encodes a second protein (denoted AzuR) that base pairs with two genes (denoted cadA and galE) and represses their expression. The RNA and protein compete for the same binding site on the two genes. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to control carbon utilization.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules. Our results provide a proof-of-concept for the use of deep learning in antibody engineering.

Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in space and time is critical to manage production and mitigate risks. Current systems rely on satellite imagery, crop models, and meteorological data, but have underutilized legacy sources of information such as crop expert surveys. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. Although the crop expert assessments are subjective and categorical, the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of leveraging the wisdom of the crowds to improve agricultural monitoring.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is capable of doing this, but the mechanisms that support it are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a significant advance in our understanding of memory in the brain. It provides a mechanism for the binding of linguistic features over time, and it is sensitive to context, which is a key property of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we present the results of the largest global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements to date. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration rates are not increasing in response to experimental warming in most biomes, and that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration is not changing with warming. These results provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The origin of plastids and the evolution of photosynthesis are among the most important events in the history of life. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key element in understanding these processes. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the loss of function in all plastid genes, which is accompanied by a relaxation of selection. Our findings provide a framework for understanding the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. They also provide a model for the evolution of molecular evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water availability in South Africa. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. This increase in drought risk is projected to increase further under future climate change. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This highlights the need for urgent adaptation measures. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, released more energy in 2 minutes (20 kilotons) than the world had released in the previous 500 years. The explosion created a blast wave that shattered glass 100 miles away, and a mushroom cloud that rose 20 miles into the air. The blast wave also created a shock wave that compressed sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as trinitite. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, in red trinitite.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. AcsF is the cyclase in R. gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein, BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is associated with the development of MS, and its severity is a major determinant of disease progression. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the development of neuroinflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a rodent model of MS. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the activation of astrocytes and microglia, which are the major cell types in the central nervous system (CNS) that are involved in neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a potential therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the development of neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. Our results suggest that additional global warming over the next few decades is very likely to create a 100% probability that any annual-scale dry period is also extremely warm. This finding has important implications for the management of water resources and the mitigation of climate change.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Our results indicate that the behavioral inflexibility of autism-risk gene mutants is caused by the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular basis for the autism phenotype and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (PsycINFO Database Record

News media are a key source of information for the general public. As such, they have a significant impact on public opinion. However, the content of news media is shaped by the economic and political interests of the news organizations that produce it. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the impact of news content on the physiological responses of participants. The results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. This work suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” (PsycINFO Database Record

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and a Stormorken-like syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are among the most devastating afflictions of the human population. The mechanisms underlying the propagation of protein aggregates in these diseases are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spreading of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. Our results provide a model for the propagation of neurodegenerative disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of the immune system in the maintenance of the bat salivary gland ecosystem and the potential for the development of new antiviral therapies. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a promising metabolic target, as it is essential for cancer cell growth, and is up-regulated in many cancers. Here we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We also show that the cancer cell-line screen reveals that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Finally, we show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer treatment. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by the aggregation of multiple proteins, including the super-aggregating superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), the aggregation-prone TDP-43, and the fused in sarcoma (FUS) protein. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We observe that the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS are a consequence of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This may provide a target for therapeutic intervention. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cold atoms are a versatile platform for exploring fundamental physics and for applications in quantum technologies. The ability to control the interactions between atoms is a key enabling technology. Here, we present a 2D photonic crystal device for controlling the interactions between cold atoms. The device is based on the band structure of a 2D photonic crystal, which can be engineered to produce a variety of unusual interactions. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride layer, which is compatible with current semiconductor fabrication processes. This opens up the possibility of deploying the device in a wide range of experiments. The device can be used to explore the physics of many-body systems and to engineer new quantum materials. It can also be used to control the interactions between cold atoms for applications in quantum technologies.

The Cretaceous is often considered to be a period of great change in the evolution of plants. The Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event, the origin of the dinosaurs, and the origin of the flowering plants are just a few of the many events that have been studied in the Cretaceous. Here we present a study of a group of plants that has been poorly understood for more than a century. We show that this group, Montsechia, is an aquatic angiosperm that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. This opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the evolution of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolutionary history of B19V is poorly understood, and the most recent common ancestor of all B19V has not been dated. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from Eurasia and Greenland that date back to ∼0.5 kya. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level has risen at an average rate of 2.9 ± 0.4 mm/y over the last 25 y. This rate is slightly higher than the rate of climate-change–driven sea level rise predicted by the most recent IPCC report. This suggests that the rate of sea level rise is not slowing down, as some had predicted.

Pain is a major public health problem, with a large economic cost. It is also a problem of growing importance as the population ages. In this paper, we show that pain is increasing in the United States, with the elderly reporting less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The atomic-resolution characterization of enzyme active sites by NMR-assisted crystallography offers a unique perspective on the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates. Here, this approach is used to study the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a detailed picture of the active site, including the location and orientation of crystallographic waters, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The study also highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the chemistry of isostere reactions. This article is protected by copyright. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there is currently no specific treatment for the novel coronavirus. The data presented here also support the use of remdesivir in the context of a clinical trial.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that a scalable intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. The intervention was simple: teachers were trained to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention was effective in reducing suspensions and increasing respect for teachers among the most at-risk students. These results have implications for policy and practice.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. Here, we show that the first cleavages are significant for virus infection because they expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. These findings may be significant for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing new strategies for controlling this deadly pathogen. This article is protected by copyright. The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large impact on these emissions. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings could have a large impact on emissions and land use change. However, the impact of increasing the proportion of plant-based meals on the population level is unknown. We show that increasing the proportion of plant-based meals by 50% in a large-scale catering setting led to a 60% increase in plant-based meals. This is equivalent to a 79% increase in the proportion of plant-based meals in the population. This is a large impact and could have a large impact on emissions and land use change.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is the collection of all the proteins that are exposed on the surface of the cell. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and a recently developed technique to measure the surfaceome of a cell line expressing six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of the proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also find that the surfaceome is remodeled by the MAPK pathway, and that this is reflected in the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. They suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a resource for the cancer research community. The 2020 presidential election is expected to be the most contested in US history. In response, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of over 500,000 Americans. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is likely to be important for immune evasion and immune suppression. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. In conclusion,

The world is full of associations. We want to know which ones are strong and which are weak. This is the problem of selective inference. It is important in the era of big data, where we have access to large datasets and sophisticated statistical methods for analyzing them. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs is still a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is independent of the expression of hematopoietic transcription factors. ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in vivo. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study provides a potential strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. It also provides a platform for the study of the development of ECs. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are implicated in cancer. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function of these receptors and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that augmentor ligands are essential for zebrafish pigment development and that these ligands are activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our findings provide insights into the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a multifactorial disease with a complex pathogenesis. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice.
